p: Th17 cells, another subset of CD4+ T-cells that reside at mucosal surfaces, play a significant role in immunity and the inflammatory response, including protecting against extracellular pathogens during autoimmune diseases [ 88, 89]. Th17 cells secrete IL-17, which serves as a chemoattractant to recruit neutrophils to the area of infection [ 90, 91]. Differentiation, stabilization, and amplification of Th17 cells is largely dependent on the presence of TGF-β, IL-1β, IL-6, IL-21, and IL-23, although the individual roles of these cytokines are known to be different across some species, most notably between mice and humans [ 88].
